questions.statement: Which of the following can be implemented using animation?
questions.explanation:
JavaScript animations are done by programming gradual changes in an element’s style. You can use JavaScript to create a complex animation which includes but not limited to:
- Fireworks
- Fade Effect
- Roll-in or Roll-out
- Page-in or Page-out
- Object movements.

questions.statement: Which is the function that calls another function after a time interval?
questions.explanation: The setTimeout(function, duration) calls function after duration milliseconds from now. setInterval(function, milliseconds) is same as setTimeout(), but repeats the execution of the function continuously.

questions.statement: Which function is used to clear the timer value?
questions.explanation: The clearTimeout() method clears a timer set with the setTimeout() method. The ID value returned by setTimeout() is used as the parameter for the clearTimeout() method.

questions.statement: Which is the property used to position the object in the left of the screen?
questions.explanation: The property object.style.left = distance in pixels or points sets distance from left edge of the screen. This property specifies the left position of the element including padding, scrollbar, border and margin. Whereas the setTimeout(function, duration) calls function after duration milliseconds from now.

questions.statement: Which is the function used to call a function in every time duration?
questions.explanation: The setInterval(function, duration) calls function after every duration milliseconds.

questions.statement: How do we get the DOM object in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: The getElementbyId() is used to get the DOM object in JavaScript by simply calling that function associated with the HTML document. The object in this method gets referenced by the id name.

questions.statement: How to assign the image source in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: For accesing any image in webpage its address or url is specified. The image source is defined as image.src = “/images/html.gif”.

questions.statement: How do we create and preload an image object in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: The Image() constructor creates and preloads a new image object. The url is specified and the image is preloaded.

options.text: Both Use new keyword and Call Image()

questions.statement: Which event handler is triggered when the user’s mouse moves onto a link?
questions.explanation: The onmouseover attribute fires when the mouse pointer moves over an element. The onmouseover attribute is often used together with the onmouseout attribute.

questions.statement: Which event handler is triggered when the user’s mouse moves away from a link?
questions.explanation: The onMouseOut event handler is triggered when the user’s mouse moves away from the link. It is often used together with onMouseOver attribute.

questions.statement: What does the interpreter do when you reference variables in other scopes?
questions.explanation: The interpreter executes the javascript code. Normally when you reference variables in other scopes at the global level, in other namespaces, and so on—the interpreter needs to traverse the stack to get to the variable.

questions.statement: The attribute location belongs to which element?
questions.explanation: window.location.href returns the href (URL) of the current page. The attribute location belongs to the document element.

questions.statement: What will happen if you reference document.location from within an object?
questions.explanation: window.location.href returns the href (URL) of the current page. If you reference document.location from within an object, the interpreter will need to go from the function that references the variable, up out of the namespace to the global window scope, down to the document scope, and gets the location value.

questions.statement: Why do we need to create locally scoped variables to hold value?
questions.explanation: window.location.assign loads a new document. The locally scoped variables are created to cache the reference to document.location.

questions.statement: What is the next step after calling the startTimeLogging()?
questions.explanation: The startTimeLogging() method captures the timing data for ad hoc, etc for referencing an uncached document.location. Once the startTimeLogging() method is called, run the code to test.

questions.statement: During the traversing through the stack, where does it go after it goes to the namespace?
questions.explanation: Namespace in JavaScript is nothing but a single global object which will contain all our functions, methods, variables and all that. During the traversal in the stack manner, after going to the namespace, it goes to the Window.

questions.statement: During the traversing through the stack, where does it go after it goes to the window?
questions.explanation: window.location.assign loads a new document. During the traversal in the stack manner, after going to the window, it goes nowhere.

questions.statement: During the traversing of the stack when you create a locally scoped variable, where does it go after it goes to the namespace?
questions.explanation: Namespace in JavaScript is nothing but a single global object which will contain all our functions, methods, variables and all that. When you create a locally scoped variable for caching the reference, the traversal reverses in the forward direction and thus, after going to the namespace, it goes to the function.

questions.statement: What is the function used to stop capturing the ad hoc timing ?
questions.explanation: The startTimeLogging() method captures the timing data for ad hoc, etc for referencing an uncached document.location. In order to stop capturing the ad hoc timing for referencing uncached document.location, we call the method stopTimeLogging().

questions.statement: During the traversing of the stack when you create a locally scoped variable, where does it go after it goes to the location?
questions.explanation: window.location.assign loads a new document. When you create a locally scoped variable for caching the reference, the traversal reverses in the forward direction and thus, after going to the location, it goes nowhere.

questions.statement: In how many modes can the closure compiler be run?
questions.explanation:
The Closure Compiler is a tool for making JavaScript download and run faster. There are totally 2 modes in which the closure compiler can be run namely:
- Simple mode
- Advanced mode.

questions.statement: What is the purpose of the simple mode?
questions.explanation: The javascript minifier compresses the javascript code. In Simple mode it mostly performs like most other minifiers, removing whitespace, line breaks, and comments.

questions.statement: What is a closure compiler UI?
questions.explanation: The Closure Compiler is a tool for making JavaScript download and runs faster. Instead of compiling from a source language to machine code, it compiles from JavaScript to better JavaScript. A closure compiler UI is a web application.

questions.statement: What are the benefits of closure compiler?
questions.explanation:
The Closure Compiler is a tool for making JavaScript download and runs faster. Instead of compiling from a source language to machine code, it compiles from JavaScript to better JavaScript. The closure compiler is highly beneficial in terms of:
- Efficiency: The Closure Compiler reduces the size of your JavaScript files and makes them more efficient, helping your application to load faster and reducing your bandwidth needs.
- Code checking: The Closure Compiler provides warnings for illegal JavaScript and warnings for potentially dangerous operations, helping you to produce JavaScript that is less buggy and easier to maintain.

questions.statement: In what way is the closure compiler efficient?
questions.explanation: The Closure Compiler is a tool for making JavaScript download and runs faster. The Closure Compiler reduces the size of your JavaScript files and makes them more efficient, helping your application to load faster and reducing your bandwidth needs.

options.text: Increases the size of the JavaScript files
Reduces the size of the JavaScript files

questions.statement: In which way can the closure compiler can be used?
questions.explanation:
Closure compiler parses your JavaScript, analyzes it, removes dead code and rewrites and minimizes what’s left. You can use the Closure Compiler as:
An open source Java application that you can run from the command line.
A simple web application.
A RESTful API.

options.text: Only Open source and Web application

questions.statement: What is the purpose of the advanced mode in the closure compiler?
questions.explanation: In Advanced mode it rewrites the JavaScript by renaming variables and functions from longer descriptive names to single letters to save file size, and it inlines functions, coalescing them into single functions wherever it determines that it can.

questions.statement: Why is a closure template used?
questions.explanation: Instead of compiling from a source language to machine code, closure templates compiles from JavaScript to better JavaScript. Closure compiler provides with the basic facilities of removing spaces and dead code. Closure Templates are a templating system for dynamically generating HTML in both Java and JavaScript. Because the language was apparently referred to as “Soy” internal to Google, and “Soy” remains in some of the documentation and classes, sometimes Closure Templates are referred to as “Soy Templates”.

options.text: To increase the efficiency and convenience
Dynamically generating HTML in Java and JavaScript

questions.statement: In what way does the closure compiler help in checking the code?
questions.explanation: Closure compiler parses your JavaScript, analyzes it, removes dead code and rewrites and minimizes what’s left. The Closure Compiler provides warnings for illegal JavaScript and warnings for potentially dangerous operations, helping you to produce JavaScript that is less buggy and easier to maintain.

questions.statement: What is the function of the closure compiler?
questions.explanation: The Closure Compiler is a tool for making JavaScript download and runs faster. It parses your JavaScript, analyzes it, removes dead code and rewrites and minimizes what’s left. It also checks syntax, variable references, and types, and warns about common JavaScript pitfalls.

options.text: Both Download faster and Run faster

questions.statement: What is it called when we make a mistake in the script?
questions.explanation: A bug in a programming language refers to a set of code which results in an error in compilation. A mistake in a script is referred to as a bug.

questions.statement: Which of the following is the definition for debugging?
questions.explanation: Debugging is the process of finding and resolving defects or problems within a computer program that prevent correct operation of computer software or a system. The process of finding and fixing bugs is called debugging and is a normal part of the development process.

questions.statement: Where is the error icon shown in the Internet Explorer?
questions.explanation: The error icon option can be enabled in the Tools. To view the console, select Tools –> Error Consol or Web Development.

questions.statement: Where is the error icon option available?
questions.explanation: The error icon option can be enabled in the Tools. To view the console, select Tools –> Error Consol or Web Development.

questions.statement: Which of the following is the window that the Firefox sends the error messages to?
questions.explanation: The browsers like Firefox, Netscape and Mozilla send error messages to a special window called the JavaScript Console or Error Console. The Error Console is deprecated in Firefox and is now only made available if you set the devtools.errorconsole.enabled preference to true.

questions.statement: What is the procedure to view the console in the Firefox?
questions.explanation: The error icon option can be enabled in the Tools. To view the console, select Tools –> Error Console or Web Development.

questions.statement: What is the other way of calling the Error Console in Firefox?
questions.explanation: The browsers like Firefox, Netscape and Mozilla send error messages to a special window called the JavaScript Console or Error Console. The Error Console is also termed as the JavaScript Console.

questions.statement: What kind of error notifications are shown in the console window?
questions.explanation: The browsers like Firefox, Netscape and Mozilla send error messages to a special window called the JavaScript Console or Error Console. Error notifications that show up on Console or through Internet Explorer dialog boxes are the result of both syntax and runtime errors. These error notification include the line number at which the error occurred.

options.text: Both Syntax error and Runtime error

questions.statement: How do we debug a script?
questions.explanation: Both the JavaScript Validator and the JavaScript Debugger can be used to debug a script. The debugger statement stops the execution of JavaScript, and calls (if available) the debugging function.

questions.statement: What is the purpose of a JavaScript debugger?
questions.explanation: A debugger is an application that places all aspects of script execution under the control of the programmer. Using the debugger statement has the same function as setting a breakpoint in the code. Debuggers provide fine-grained control over the state of the script through an interface that allows you to examine and set values as well as control the flow of execution.

options.text: Correction of errors & Placing script execution under control

questions.statement: In which format does JavaScript support external JavaScript?
questions.explanation: JavaScript supports external JavaScript, in the form of .js file. This extension can be captured by a number of applications including: Windows Script Host, Dreamweaver MX, Notepad, Netscape Navigator, PavScrip, UltraEdit. The files are generally text files.

questions.statement: What are the two parts of JavaScript libraries?
questions.explanation:
All JavaScript libraries consists of two parts:
The external JavaScript itself, which is simply a text file with the containing JavaScript code, saved as a .js file.
A “script” tag referencing the external JavaScript file and defined on the page(s) that uses the library.
The <script> element either contains scripting statements, or it points to an external script file through the src attribute.

questions.statement: Which of the following is added to prefs.js when the console is automatically opened during JavaScript error?
questions.explanation:
The prefs.js file, located in the profile folder, is used by Firefox and other Mozilla-based applications to store settings. For instance, when you create a new e-mail account in Thunderbird, the account name and server settings will be stored in the prefs.js file in your Thunderbird profile folder.
The code :
user_pref("javascript.console.open_on_error", true);
is added to prefs.js when the console is automatically opened during JavaScript error.

questions.statement: Which of the following is possible to be referenced in external JavaScript?
questions.explanation: PHP (recursive acronym for PHP: Hypertext Preprocessor) is a widely-used open source general-purpose scripting language that is especially suited for web development and can be embedded into HTML. One of the lesser known sides of external JavaScript is the ability to reference a PHP file instead of the familiar .js file.

questions.statement: Which of the following attribute takes the source of the PHP file?
questions.explanation:
Php file is used an scripting language for backend development. The syntax to referencing a PHP file using external JavaScript is consistent enough with what we already know:
<script type="text/javascript" src="myscript.php"></script>

questions.statement: What kind of path can the PHP file be?
questions.explanation: The PHP code is enclosed in special start and end processing instructions <?php and ?> that allows you to jump into and out of “PHP mode”. The PHP file is either an absolute or relative path to a PHP script instead of the usual .js file.

questions.statement: Which of the following global variables is used to get parameters?
questions.explanation: The global variable $HTTP_GET_VARS[] is used to get parameters. $HTTP_GET_VARS contains the same initial information, but is not a superglobal.

questions.statement: What is the purpose of the RegExp method test()?
questions.explanation: RegExp stands for regular expression which is an object that describes a pattern of characters.

options.text: Tests for a match in its float parameter
Tests for a match in its string parameter
Tests for a match in its integer parameter
Test for a match in node

questions.statement: What is the purpose of the function parameter filetype?
questions.explanation: The File.type property is an inbuilt function of File WebAPI which gives the media type (MIME) of the file represented by a file object. The function parameter “filetype” lets you tell the script what file type to expect before loading.

options.text: File type that should not be got

questions.statement: Which of the following is the method used to add an element to the desired location?
questions.explanation: The method element.appendChild() is used to add the element to the desired location within the document tree. The appendChild() method appends a node as the last child of a node.

questions.statement: Which program code doesn’t need preprocessing before being run?
questions.explanation: A scripting or script language is a programming language for a special run-time environment that automates the execution of tasks. A script is program code that doesn’t need pre-processing (e.g. compiling) before being run.

questions.statement: What is the significance of scripting?
questions.explanation: Scripting languages are often interpreted (rather than compiled). Scripting makes Web pages more dynamic) For example, without reloading a new version of a page it may allow modifications to the content of that page, or allow content to be added to or sent from that page. The former has been called DHTML (Dynamic HTML), and the latter AJAX (Asynchronous JavaScript and XML).

questions.statement: What is the purpose of XMLHttpRequest?
questions.explanation: The XMLHttpRequest object can be used to request data from a web server. XMLHttpRequest makes it possible to load additional content from the Web without loading a new document, a core component of AJAX.

options.text: Load content by loading new document
Load content without loading new document

questions.statement: Which API makes the user’s current location available to browser-based application?
questions.explanation: The Geolocation API allows the user to provide their location to web applications if they so desire. For privacy reasons, the user is asked for permission to report location information.

questions.statement: Which of the following ensures additional interactivity mechanism?
questions.explanation: Web Accessibility Initiative – Accessible Rich Internet Applications (WAI-ARIA) is a technical specification published by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) that specifies how to increase the accessibility of web pages, in particular, dynamic content, and user interface components developed with Ajax, HTML, JavaScript, and related technologies. WAI ARIA offers mechanisms to ensure that this additional interactivity remains usable independent of devices and disabilities.

questions.statement: What is the necessity to have API?
questions.explanation: In computer programming, an application programming interface is a set of subroutine definitions, communication protocols, and tools for building software. An API may describe the ways in which a particular task is performed.

options.text: Both performing activities and Describe particular task

questions.statement: What is the purpose of the event onAirEvent?
questions.explanation: The event onAirEvent is fired when the player starts playing content being broadcasted on the channel. The method is called at the time of the creation of adspace.

options.text: Both Content is played and transferred

questions.statement: What is the purpose of the event disconnectionEvent?
questions.explanation: navigator.onLine is a property that maintains a true/false value (true for online, false for offline). This property is updated whenever the user switches into “Offline Mode”. The event disconnectionEvent is fired when the player disconnects from the channel, whether a result of user interaction or not.

questions.statement: When does one use the event ready?
questions.explanation: The ready event occurs when the DOM (document object model) has been loaded. It is safe to interact with it after this event fired.

questions.statement: When does one use the method startOverlays()?
questions.explanation: A new ad request is made every time when the method startOverlays() gets called. It is used at the time of creation of the ad.

questions.statement: What is the reason for avoiding the attributes property in the HTML DOM?
questions.explanation: When a web page is loaded, the browser creates a Document Object Model of the page. The reason for avoiding the attributes property in the HTML DOM is because Attributes don’t have attributes.

questions.statement: What is the purpose of the method nodeMap.setNamedItem()?
questions.explanation: The setNamedItem() method adds the specified node to the NamedNodeMap. The method nodeMap.setNamedItem() sets the specified attribute node (by name).

questions.statement: How is everything treated in HTML DOM?
questions.explanation:
The HTML DOM model is constructed as a tree of Objects. In the HTML DOM (Document Object Model), everything is a node:
-The document itself is a document node.
-All HTML elements are element nodes.
-All HTML attributes are attribute nodes.
-Text inside HTML elements are text nodes.
-Comments are comment nodes.

questions.statement: What does the NamedNodeMap object represent in the HTML DOM?
questions.explanation: In the HTML DOM, the NamedNodeMap object represents an unordered collection of an elements attribute nodes. The nodes in the NamedNodeMap can be accessed through their name.

questions.statement: What is the purpose of the Attr object in the HTML DOM?
questions.explanation: When a web page is loaded, the browser creates a Document Object Model of the page. In the HTML DOM, the Attr object represents an HTML attribute.

options.text: Used to focus on a particular part of the HTML page

questions.statement: What is the work of the form control elements in the HTML DOM?
questions.explanation: Form control elements: The form object contains all the elements defined for that object such as text fields, buttons, radio buttons, and checkboxes. The elements collection returns a collection of all elements in a form.

questions.statement: How are the objects organized in the HTML DOM?
questions.explanation: The HTML DOM model is constructed as a tree of Objects. The objects are organized in the hierarchy format in the HTML DOM.

questions.statement: Which of the following is a type of HTML DOM?
questions.explanation: IE4 document object model was introduced in Version 4 of Microsoft’s Internet Explorer browser. IE 5 and later versions include support for most basic W3C DOM features. All of the above mentioned are types of HTML DOM.

questions.statement: What is the purpose of the Legacy DOM?
questions.explanation: The Legacy DOM: This is the model which was introduced in early versions of JavaScript language. It is well supported by all browsers but allows access only to certain key portions of documents, such as forms, form elements, and images.

options.text: Allows access to few keys and elements

questions.statement: Which object is the top of the hierarchy?
questions.explanation: The  DOM is arranged in the form of tree with every node as an object. Window object is the top of the hierarchy. It is the outmost element of the object hierarchy.

questions.statement: Which side of the image map can be created using JavaScript?
questions.explanation: Javascript is used for the creation of client side data. You can use JavaScript to create client side image map.

questions.statement: Which is the attribute used to enable the Client-side image map?
questions.explanation: The usemap attribute is associated with a element’s name or id attribute, and creates a relationship between the and the .

questions.statement: Which are the special tags used for image mapping?
questions.explanation: The usemap attribute specifies an image (or an object) as an image-map (an image-map is an image with clickable areas). The special tags used for image mapping are map and area.

questions.statement: Which is the element that follows the use of “img”?
questions.explanation: The usemap attribute is associated with a element’s name or id attribute, and creates a relationship between the and the . The “map” element actually creates the map for the image and usually follows directly after the “img ” element.

options.text: any element can follow the use of “img”

questions.statement: What is the purpose of the area element?
questions.explanation: The <area> tag defines an area inside an image-map (an image-map is an image with clickable areas). The <area> element is always nested inside a <map> tag. The area element specifies the shape and the coordinates that define the boundaries of each clickable hotspot.

options.text: Shape and coordinates of the hotspot
Shape and area of the hotspot

questions.statement: Which of the following is not a navigator property?
questions.explanation: The navigator object contains information about the browser. All of the above mentioned are the properties of a navigator.

questions.statement: What is the purpose of the platform[] property in a navigator?
questions.explanation: The platform[] property is a string that contains the platform for which the browser was compiled. “Win32” for 32-bit Windows operating systems.

options.text: Platform where the image map was designed
Platform where the browser was compiled
Platform where the plugin was designed

questions.statement: What is the purpose of the preference method in a navigator?
questions.explanation: The preference(name,value) method allows a signed script to get and set some Netscape preferences. If the second parameter is omitted, this method will return the value of the specified preference; otherwise, it sets the value Netscape only.

questions.statement: Which of the following is not a navigator method?
questions.explanation: The preference(name, value) method allows a signed script to get and set some Netscape preferences. If the second parameter is omitted, this method will return the value of the specified preference; otherwise, it sets the value Netscape only.

questions.statement: What is the purpose of the userAgent property?
questions.explanation: The userAgent[] property is a string that contains the code name and version of the browser. This value is sent to the originating server to identify the client. The userAgent property returns the value of the user-agent header sent by the browser to the server.

options.text: Both Identifying the data and client

questions.statement: Where are memory leaks found?
questions.explanation: Memory leaks happen when your code needs to consume memory in your application, which should be released after a given task is completed but isn’t. Memory leaks occur when we are developing client-side reusable scripting objects.

options.text: Both Client side and Server side objects

questions.statement: Which handler is triggered when the content of the document in the window is stable and ready for manipulation?
questions.explanation: One of the most important event handlers is the onload handler of the Window object. It is triggered when the content of the document displayed in the window is stable and ready to be manipulated. JavaScript code is commonly wrapped within an onload event handler.

questions.statement: What is the central concept of JavaScript memory management?
questions.explanation:
The central concept of JavaScript memory management is a concept of reachability. The main cause for leaks in garbage collected languages are unwanted references.
A distinguished set of objects are assumed to be reachable: these are known as the roots. Typically, these include all the objects referenced from anywhere in the call stack (that is, all local variables and parameters in the functions currently being invoked), and any global variables.
Objects are kept in memory while they are accessible from roots through a reference or a chain of references.

questions.statement: When does a memory leak happen?
questions.explanation: Memory leaks happen when your code needs to consume memory in your application, which should be released after a given task is complete but isn’t. Memory leak happens when the browser for some reason doesn’t release memory from objects which are not needed any more.

options.text: Browser doesn’t release memory from objects unnecessary

questions.statement: What will happen when the data of the jQuery.cache is read from an element?
questions.explanation:
jQuery.cache[id] is used to associate handlers and other data with elements. When the data is read from an element:
The element unique number is retrieved from id = elem[ jQuery.expando].
The data is read from jQuery.cache[id].

options.text: Unique number is retrieved as elem[jQuery.expando]
Unique number is retrieved as elem[jQuery.expando] & Data is read from jQuery.cache[id]

questions.statement: The style property belongs to which of the following object?
questions.explanation: Each Element object has style and className properties that allow scripts to specify CSS styles for a document element or to alter the CSS class names that apply to the element.

questions.statement: Which of the following functions are referenced internally?
questions.explanation: setTimeout(function, milliseconds) executes a function, after waiting a specified number of milliseconds. Functions used in setTimeout/setInterval are referenced internally and tracked until complete, then cleaned up.

questions.statement: What is the purpose of destroying the functions and objects?
questions.explanation:
The primary purpose of a destroy function is to centralize the responsibility for cleaning up anything that the object has done that will:
Prevent its reference count from dropping to 0 (for example, removing problematic event listeners and callbacks and unregistering from any services).
Consume unnecessary CPU cycles, such as intervals or animations.

options.text: Prevent the dropping of reference count to 0
Centralize the responsibility to clean up

questions.statement: When does a cycle occur during memory leak?
questions.explanation: Old versions of Internet Explorer could not detect cyclic references between DOM nodes and JavaScript code. A cycle happens when two objects reference each other in such a way that both objects retain each other.

questions.statement: Which of the following is a way to retain an object in memory?
questions.explanation: Any object inside the timer will hold a reference in order to run that piece of code somewhere in the future without any problems. One particularly obscure way to retain an object in memory is to log it to the console.

questions.statement: BLOB stands for ______________
questions.explanation: A Blob is an opaque reference to, or handle for, a chunk of data. The name comes from SQL databases, where it means “Binary Large Object.” In JavaScript, Blobs often represent binary data, and they can be large, but neither is required: a Blob could also represent the contents of a small text file.

questions.statement: The size of blobs are generally calculated in ____________
questions.explanation: A Blob object represents a file-like object of immutable, raw data. Blobs represent data that isn’t necessarily in a JavaScript-native format. Blobs are opaque all you can do with them directly is determine their size in bytes, ask for their MIME type, and chop them up into smaller Blobs.

questions.statement: The blobs are generally stored in ____________
questions.explanation: A Blob object represents a file-like object of immutable, raw data. The web browser can store Blobs in memory or on disk, and Blobs can represent really enormous chunks of data (such as video files) that are too large to fit in main memory without first being broken into smaller pieces with slice().

questions.statement: The blobs are broken into smaller pieces using which of the following functions?
questions.explanation: The File interface is based on Blob, inheriting blob functionality and expanding it to support files on the user’s system. The web browser can store Blobs in memory or on disk, and Blobs can represent really enormous chunks of data (such as video files) that are too large to fit in main memory without first being broken into smaller pieces with slice().

questions.statement: Which algorithm supports blobs?
questions.explanation: Blobs represent data that isn’t necessarily in a JavaScript-native format. Blobs are supported by the structured clone algorithm, which means that you can obtain one from another window or thread via the message event.

questions.statement: Which database can be used to retrieve blobs?
questions.explanation: A Blob object represents a file-like object of immutable, raw data. Blobs represent data that isn’t necessarily in a JavaScript-native format. Blobs can be retrieved from client-side databases.

questions.statement: Which object can be used to create your own blobs?
questions.explanation: Blobs represent data that isn’t necessarily in a JavaScript-native format. You can create your own blobs, using a BlobBuilder object to build them out of strings, ArrayBuffer objects, and other Blobs.

questions.statement: Which of the following is a subtype of Blob?
questions.explanation: The File interface is based on Blob, inheriting blob functionality and expanding it to support files on the user’s system. The client-side JavaScript File object is a subtype of Blob: a File is just a Blob of data with a name and a modification date.

questions.statement: Which method facilitates in uploading a Blob to a server?
questions.explanation: The Blob() constructor allows one to create blobs from other objects. You can upload a Blob to a server by passing it to the send() method of an XMLHttpRequest object.

questions.statement: A Blob URL can be created using which of the following function?
questions.explanation: The Blob() constructor allows one to create blobs from other objects. Create a Blob URL with the function createObjectURL(). At the time of this writing, the draft specification and Firefox 4 put this function in a global object named URL, and Chrome and Webkit prefix that new global, calling it webkitURL.

questions.statement: What is the framework?
questions.explanation: A framework, or software framework, is a platform for developing software applications. Frameworks are an author-time efficiency, meaning that they make coding tasks much simpler by abstracting the real work that goes into doing those tasks.

options.text: Both User time and Author time efficiency

questions.statement: Which is the function used to loop in an array to view all the values?
questions.explanation: for.each() function is used for traversing through each values of the array. The method jQuery.each(array, function) loops through the array.

questions.statement: Which of the following has a greater benchmark time for looping and JQuery vs core JavaScript in milliseconds?
questions.explanation: jQuery Injector allows you to inject jQuery into every frame on a page so that you can use jQuery in the chrome dev console. When we try to compare the average benchmark time for looping and JQuery vs core JavaScript in milliseconds, the Chrome JQuery has a greater benchmark time.

questions.statement: Which class provides an interface for invoking JavaScript methods and examining JavaScript properties?
questions.explanation: JSObject is the type of JavaScript objects in the JSAPI. When a JavaScript object is passed or returned to Java code, it is wrapped in an instance of JSObject. When a JSObject instance is passed to the JavaScript engine, it is unwrapped back to its original JavaScript object. The JSObject class provides a way to invoke JavaScript methods and examine JavaScript properties.

questions.statement: What is the purpose of the function eval?

questions.statement: Which of the following is one of the fundamental features of JavaScript?

questions.statement: What will happen if you specify an absolute URL in the Worker constructor?

questions.statement: How can you send data using a Worker object?

The value you pass to postMessage() will be cloned, and the resulting copy will be delivered to the worker via a message event. postMessage() sends a message — which can consist of any JavaScript object — to the worker’s inner scope.
loader.postMessage("file.txt");

questions.statement: Which property is used to manage multiple event handlers?
questions.explanation: message event is fired when the worker’s parent receives a message from its worker which is also available via the onmessage property. You can use onmessage and onerror properties if you want to manage multiple event handlers.

questions.statement: Which is the function that allows a worker to terminate itself?

questions.statement: Why was “The Good Parts” designed as a language subset in JavaScript?

questions.statement: Which are the two functions that are not allowed in any secure subset?

questions.statement: Which is the object that defines methods that allow complete control over page content?

questions.statement: Which was one of the first security subsets proposed?
questions.explanation: ADsafe was one of the first security subsets proposed) It was created by Douglas Crockford (who also defined The Good Parts subset). ADsafe relies on static verification only, and it uses JSLint as its verifier. It forbids access to most global variables and defines an ADSAFE variable that provides access to a secure API, including special-purpose DOM methods. ADsafe is not in wide use, but it was an influential proof-of-concept that influenced other secure subsets.

questions.statement: Which is the subset that transforms web content into secure modules that can be safely hosted on a web page?
questions.explanation: Caja is Google’s open-source secure subset. Caja (Spanish for “box”) defines two language subsets. Cajita (“little box”) is a narrow subset like that used by ADsafe and dojox.secure. Valija (“suitcase” or “baggage”) is a much broader language that is close to regular ECMAScript 5 strict mode (with the removal of eval()). Caja itself is the name of the compiler that transforms (or “cajoles”) web content (HTML, CSS, and JavaScript code) into secure modules that can be safely hosted on a web page without being able to affect the page as a whole or other modules on the page.

exec() returns the same kind of array whether or not the regular expression has the global g flag. Recall that match() returns an array of matches when passed a global regular expression. exec(), by contrast, always returns a single match and provides complete information about that match. When exec() is called on a regular expression that has the g flag, it sets the lastIndex property of the regular expression object to the character position immediately following the matched substring. When exec() is invoked a second time for the same regular expression, it begins its search at the character position indicated by the lastIndex property. If exec() does not find a match, it resets lastIndex to 0.

The \v metacharacter is used to find a vertical tab character. \v returns the position where the vertical tab character was found. If no match is found, it returns -1.
The \xxx character is used to find the Latin character specified by an octal number xxx. If no match is found, it returns null.
The \xdd character is used to find the Latin character specified by a hexadecimal number dd. The character ‘W’ is represented as x57 in hexadecimal.
The \udddd character is used to find the Unicode character specified by a hexadecimal number dddd. If no match is found, it returns null.
The \W metacharacter is used to find a non-word character. A word character is a character from a-z, A-Z, 0-9, including the _ (underscore) character.
